video.title: What I Gained After 100 Days of Code
video.description:
This talk is about “scaling yourself” and what I learned after the #100DaysOfCode challenge. I will present some helpful tips about self-motivation, time-management, stop procrastination, setting priorities, staying organized, believing in yourself and keeping a balance between your career and personal life. I'm going to present my personal examples of coding/studying every single day for the past 1,5 years, what I gained and how I achieved my goals. We are going to explore ways of finding mentors, friends and expanding your social network. This talk is not only about getting better at your 9 to 5 job but also about developing yourself.

Talk by Eleftheria Batsou at Codegarden.

🐦Eleftheria on Twitter: https://twitter.com/BatsouElef
📹 See more from Eleftheria on her channel: https://www.youtube.com/c/EleftheriaBatsou

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

replies.author: Eleftheria Batsou
replies.text:
Yeap, after high school I was in a polytechnical university (which means 5 years!! and I majored in Informatics and Telecommunications of engineering)
After that, I did an internship in the Netherlands  (front-end developer)
I found a job in Greece (front-end developer)
And by the time I was giving this presentation, I had found my 2nd job (an app developer) and started my masters (graphic arts and multimedia)

replies.author: Albert S
replies.text: @ZackAttack Thank you, I really have one: When should I move on from JS? I am good with DOM manipulation and can do a lot with Arrays and Objects. I also build HTML tables with JS (two different ways). What else should I try my hands on before moving on?

replies.author: ZackAttack
replies.text: It depends on what exactly you are trying to learn and what career roadmap you are trying to fulfill. If you are looking to do web development I would look into the 2019 web development roadmap that gives you a look into some different routes for frontend development as well as backend development. If you have any questions let me know.

topLevelComment.author: e4r
topLevelComment.text: "Game of Life is very complicated" ? lol

replies.author: freeCodeCamp.org
replies.text: A basic static HTML page is hard if you've never done it before but then it's easy once you've done it many times. The Game of Life is a very complicated project for people just learning to code.

replies.author: e4r
replies.text:
Well, you can explain the game in 4 simple rules :

1 - Any live cell with fewer than two live neighbors dies.
2 - Any live cell with two or three live neighbors lives on.
3 - Any live cell with more than three live neighbors dies.
4 - Any dead cell with exactly three live neighbors becomes a live cell.

That's all there is to it.

replies.author: Eleftheria Batsou
replies.text:
For me... it was! 
It was my first time approaching a game like that. There are many videos on youtube that actually just explain the game. I guess if it was a simple one, no one would bother explaining it, but that s just my opinion :)
